Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Temporal Geocoder: A Collaborative Software Tool for Connecting Historical Materials with Contemporary Place
Award.AbstractNarration:
The innovation is a new approach to structuring, collecting and using historical geospatial data that will make it possible to rapidly assign a geographic location for text descriptions appearing in historic documents. Geospatial location is a critical element of most documents, and historical archives are no exception. Geocoding, the assignment of coordinates to a geographic reference, is the key task required to enable geographic searching of historical databases. While geocoding technology has continued to advance, current digital mapping systems focus on contemporary location references, and an urban scale temporal geocoder has yet to be developed. Such a service would take not only an address, intersection or place name as an input but also a time period, enabling accurate identification of its contemporary location on the urban landscape even when street names and other reference information have changed over the years. New database structures and processing algorithms will be developed that translate street addresses from any documented time period into contemporary geographic coordinates. Collaborative data collection and quality assessment tools will enable individuals with varying skillsets across diverse locations to update, edit, and refine the historic geographic and temporal data that will populate the database.

The broader/commercial impact is the development of temporally-enabled geographic databases that will support both new and more effective use of historical data for research in public health, political science, criminology, social science, genealogy and any other subject where the connection between past and present is important. Street names, place names and addressing systems in our cities change a great deal over time. The dynamic nature of urban geography in particular has long been a barrier to the use of historic directories, property deeds, atlases, and other archival materials as a means of understanding the relationships between geographic location and the human condition. While current commercial and open source geocoders can help researchers navigate the contemporary landscape, the ability to tag documents with a geographic location at a specific time will unlock an entirely new dimension of human knowledge by bringing digital scholarship and research to archives that are largely untapped. In addition to generating new knowledge about the past, a collaborative platform for creating, maintaining, accessing, and viewing temporal geographic data is a significant business opportunity. The initial project will focus on the City of Philadelphia, but the resulting framework will be applicable to any location in the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Temporal Geocoder is a web-based software project that enables users to determine the current geographic locations associated with addresses, place names, and locations mentioned in historic materials. As many libraries and other cultural institutions digitize books, city directories, maps, atlases, and other printed items, the amount of historic information available online has increased rapidly. 

Often, these materials include references to geographic locations. Address numbers and street names are dynamic in nature, however, and tend to both change and shift over time, particularly in urban locations where streets are renamed and renumbered during times of city consolidation and construction. While the physical address of 850 Brandywine Street in Philadelphia may be associated with the geographic coordinates of 39.958718, -75.158395 in 2013, that address could easily be associated with a completely different set of coordinates in 1913.  And the physical location may have been known as 850 Depot Street in 1896. 

The Temporal Geocoder software enables organizations to consult historic documents and compile a record of geographic changes in a spatial database. The software includes two main elements – an administrative system for adding records of geographic changes and a search system for exploring the gathered data.

In the administrative interface, organizations can upload a historic map and display it with an overlay of the current street grid. Different users can then indicate a street segment, point, or building on the historic map and enter metadata (information) about that object. Metadata may include street names, address ranges, building names, and information found in accompanying non-spatial resources such as city ordinances and business directories. The Temporal Geocoder has varying permission levels that enable an organization to allow trained assistants or a broader audience of the general public to add annotations to the map or review and verify existing annotations.

By adding annotations about the street segments on a historic map, users build a database of historic geographic information that is connected to contemporary geographic locations. The search interface enables users to browse through this information and find locations by address or place name. Users can enter a year or year range to limit the search results or leave the year field blank to see all locations associated with the address or place name.

The Temporal Geocoder software will search the system for the clearest match between the entered address and an address in the database. If the user did not enter a date range, the software will display on the map all locations that were ever associated with that address.

The results of our Phase I grant work on the Temporal Geocoder included designing a database that supported both geospatial and temporal information, developing a collaborative data editor, and designing prototypes of the user interfaces for the software. A publicly available version of the Temporal Geocoder is not yet available. As we continue work on the project, the Temporal Geocoder will provide opportunities for researchers, students, and the general public to explore important geospatial information found in digitized historic materials and provide new resources for study and analysis.  


Last Modified: 02/26/2014
Modified by: Robert M Cheetham
